Following â€˜The Endless Riverâ€™, Gilmour and Waters continued to tour. There was a new Roger Waters album â€˜Is This the Life we Really Want?â€™, and a new Gilmour live album and DVD called â€˜Live at Pompeiiâ€™ â€“ the story continues, even with both men in their seventies. You canâ€™t help feeling that this canâ€™t go on much longer, but many strange things have happened over the decadesâ€¦

Once upon a time, there was a rock and roll band. They were just like any band of young men; eager for fame, fortune and the attention of girls, but they were extremely fortunate to have come into existence at one of the key moments of change in popular music; just as they were ditching the name The Tea Set in favour of something a bit more interesting, they discovered that they could extend their meagre repertoire of blues-based songs by stretching the solos out and improvising madly over them, and not only did the audience not object, some of them sat down, took mind-altering substances and actually listened.

In 1967, you could do anything you liked, and as long as you appeared proficient on your instruments and seemed to have a purpose to your noise, you could swing a lengthy record contract. You could grow your hair, ditch the suits, stare intently at the floor in search of inspiration, make music with hammers and nails, and youâ€™d still have an audience. You could put out records about cross-dressing and get in the charts; you could make an album which was half psychedelic space rock and half mind-altered English whimsy, and people would buy it in their thousands.

Most importantly, in the late 1960s, you could take three years and five albums to find your feet, and your record company would stand by you; even â€“ in their own way â€“ encourage you. And when that happens, and you replace your erratic lead singer with someone who appears to be on the same page as the rest of you, then you really can go on to fame and fortune and all the other things you dreamed about.

None of the band meant for it to get as big as it did. You can argue that there was no real precedent for what happened to Pink Floyd â€“ all the bands who came before them, and sold records in comporable quantities, were singles bands first; they blazed a trail, but they were household names, and they released singles; you could mess one of those up, and bounce back a few weeks later. If the only thing you did was make albums, and you had no public face, then you pretty much had to get it right every time. No wonder it all fell apart.

Thereâ€™s a moment during â€˜Echoesâ€™ when you can hear it all clicking into place; following the slightly erratic middle section, the band gradually returns to the disciplined rhythm of the beginning, the sonar ping returns, followed by that metronomic bassline and â€“ if youâ€™re an impressionable teenager like me â€“ you can feel yourself being lifted out of your seat by something quite unlike anything youâ€™ve heard before. The music gets in your head and it blocks out all other thoughts, then it settles in for a long stay â€“ forty-five years and counting, in my case. The remarkable thing about the music of Pink Floyd is that they did that trick over and over again; they managed to get you to go back to the earlier stuff and hear the seeds of it all; they kept producing new music and making your brain do the same trick, until one day you wake up and realise that the band you thought you were listening to is gone, and in its place is something cold and hard, which doesnâ€™t sound much like the band you loved.

Yet it doesnâ€™t matter â€“ thereâ€™s something about even the caustic version of Pink Floyd which retains the magic; there are moments â€“ fewer of them, perhaps, as time goes by â€“ when you can still hear it all pull together and make something more than the sum of its parts.

When the band reached the end of the road, not all its members agreed. They had been through the most tumultuous experience itâ€™s possible to imagine; had created music which will endure in the way the music of Bach or Mozart has endured, and it destroyed them. We shouldnâ€™t be too harsh; there isnâ€™t a manual on how to behave when these things happen, and musical genius doesnâ€™t play by everyone elseâ€™s rules, in any case. What was left of the band limped on, produced sporadically interesting music, and finally bowed to the inevitable.

Once upon a time there was a rock and roll band. They werenâ€™t very good at first, but they lived in a time of possibilities, and their possibilities led them into realms unimagined, even by the wildest of dreamers. Of course the journey took its toll; every journey worth the name does. If friendships were broken, and fortunes made and lost, it was in the cause of creating something immortal, and that had to be worth something. At the end of every good quest, the heroes get to take a bow, and be recognised for what they have achieved; and that, for people of my generation, was what the evening of July 2nd, 2005 was about. The greatest band of our generation; the one who created so many of the paths for others to follow, and so many of the indelible memories of our youth, were getting their moment to see just what it had all meant to us, and we, in turn had one last chance to express what we felt. It felt special because it was special â€“ everyone has â€˜their bandâ€™; the one which matters more to them than all the others, for a significant portion of the world, that band was Pink Floyd.

Throughout this journey, I have probably given a false impression. Pink Floyd arenâ€™t that band for me; I have others I love more, and whose stories and music affect me more viscerally. But thereâ€™s something epic about the Floyd story; something irresistible about the way it all happened, and â€“ for me â€“ the way it all happened in front of me, as I was discovering this music. I do love more of their music than most bands; I havenâ€™t been falsely representing my feelings. But itâ€™s a measure of the band that, even if they arenâ€™t that band for me, I can still find so much to say about them; I can still remember when I first heard so much of their music, and I can still react so urgently to music which is getting on for 50 years old. Why does it matter so much?

Well, in some ways, it doesnâ€™t. Who cares what I think; itâ€™s only music â€“ change the channel and thereâ€™ll be something else on; something new; something youâ€™ve never heard before, and which will lift you out of your seat the way â€˜Echoesâ€™ did. And no-oneâ€™s right, and no-oneâ€™s wrong â€“ itâ€™s all just opinion; all just noise. Fashions come and fashions go, and todayâ€™s superstars are tomorrowâ€™s nostalgia circuit. Itâ€™s all just noise.

Except, you know, it isnâ€™t. Itâ€™s so much more than that.

Thanks for listening.

Some things to consider if youâ€™re coming to this new:

You might well be wondering: â€œwhat the hellâ€™s this?â€ if you are coming to it new. The truthful answer to that is â€œI donâ€™t really knowâ€, but letâ€™s try to find out.

The Division Bell tour was a spectacular success in a great many ways â€“ the band themselves seemed to actually be enjoying it for once, the set list contained a great deal of older material, including â€˜Astronomy Dominieâ€™ and the whole of â€˜Dark Sideâ€™, and vast amounts of money were made via the live album (called â€˜PULSE) and â€“ after an entirely unexplained gap of ten years â€“ the live DVD of the same name.

Incidentally, the original CD release of â€˜Pulseâ€™ had a flashing LED set into the spine; mine wore out after a year or so; apparently you could replace the battery if you were really intent on keeping it goingâ€¦

Anyway, hereâ€™s a bit:

On October 29th, 1994, Pink Floyd gave their last ever full-length performance; itâ€™s not clear if everyone knew this was the end of the road at the time, but there really doesnâ€™t seem to have ever been any enthusiasm for doing anything more from any of them; 12 years after Roger Waters pronounced it, Pink Floyd finally ceased to be.

Of course, that didnâ€™t stop people from making lots of money from them. Almost before the dust had settled on â€˜Pulseâ€™, various compilations and reissues started appearing. Thereâ€™s an EP called â€˜London 66-67â€™ which features the previously unreleased â€˜Nickâ€™s Boogieâ€™:

There were various compilations, most notably the 2001 collection â€˜Echoesâ€™, which required all four band members to agree on a track listing â€“ a singularly painful process by all accounts â€“ it features a Storm Thorgerson cover in the style of â€˜Ummagummaâ€™, and is presented in what was claimed to be a â€˜thematicâ€™ order, rather than chronologically, so can seem a little schizophrenic at times, but perhaps thatâ€™s apt. A number of the longer tracks are edited for length, leaving it a little unsatisfying in places, but if you were only ever going to own one Pink Floyd album, I supposeâ€¦ actually, no. Donâ€™t do that; buy â€˜Animalsâ€™ instead, and with what youâ€™ve got left over, buy â€˜Dark Side of the Moonâ€™. Thank me later.

Compilations begat boxed sets of remasters, which in turn begat another compilation entitled â€˜A Foot in the Doorâ€™, which sounds like an edited highlights version of â€˜Echoesâ€™. Itâ€™s all a bit pointless, really, but it must make money for someone.

As all this repackaging and reissuing was going on, the various members also pressed on with solo work. Roger Waters released his own solo compilation in 2001, then wrote an opera called â€˜Ã‡a Iraâ€™ about the French revolution. Itâ€™s, by all accounts, not particularly great (Iâ€™ve never felt the urge to listen to it all) â€“ this is the overture:

Waters also issued a handful of singles over the years â€“ â€˜To Kill the Childâ€™ is typical; lyrically exactly what youâ€™d expect, with a soaring chorus drowned in backing vocals:

(he has gradually come to sound like Mark Knopfler as heâ€™s aged, hasnâ€™t he?)

David Gilmour gradually settled into a solo career which afforded him the respect he obviously feels he deserves; he makes a lot of money from touring these days, and seems especially popular in eastern Europe. Both â€˜On an Islandâ€™ and â€˜Rattle That Lockâ€™ are perfectly fine examples of comfortable, middle-aged rock. You canâ€™t help feeling that the thousands who still flock to his shows are going to see him do â€˜Comfortably Numbâ€™, though.

Gilmour is also in enormous demand as a session musician (or â€˜guest musicianâ€™, as I have no doubt heâ€™d prefer to be called) â€“ over the years, heâ€™s appeared on everything from a B.B King session to the Ben Watt / Bernard Butler album â€˜Hendraâ€™, as well as collaborating with The Orb on â€˜Metallic Spheresâ€™:

He also continues from time to time to work with Kate Bush, who he discovered when she was still a teenager â€“ thereâ€™s a whole story there, which I never could quite fit in to the overall picture, but, in essence, we have Gilmour to thank for Kate Bush.

Nick Mason made some more albums with Michael Mantler, but his main post-Floyd project was to write a book, â€˜Inside Outâ€™, which chronicles the whole story â€“ itâ€™s been invaluable these past few weeks when there have been details which have escaped me, and I highly recommend it; heâ€™s an engaging writer, although as he admits, his is only one version of the Pink Floyd story.

Rick Wright released one more solo album- â€˜Broken Chinaâ€™ in 1996; the title track features Sinead Oâ€™Connor:

He then spent the next years touring with Gilmour, appearing on some of the tracks on Gilmourâ€™s solo albums. Wrightâ€™s daughter married Guy Pratt; you should also read Prattâ€™s book â€˜My Bass and other Animalsâ€™ for his insight into how that all worked â€“ appearing on stage with your father-in-law didnâ€™t always go smoothly!

And that ought really to have been that, except Bob Geldof can do miracles.

Quick, without looking: who headlined the Live 8 concert in Hyde Park? It wasnâ€™t Pink Floyd, but youâ€™d be forgiven for assuming it was. Paul McCartney had the unenviable task of having to follow that; Iâ€™m sure I watched it to the bitter end; Iâ€™m equally sure I wasnâ€™t really taking it all in, and donâ€™t remember a note of it.

Geldof had decided that getting Floyd back together would be the best way of promoting his event (anyone remember what it was really all about, beyond vague protest and a neat slogan about making poverty history? Thought not.) It seemed the unlikeliest of long shots, but somehow â€“ by approaching everyone in the right order, and doing the whole â€˜Ah, go onâ€™ thing in the inimitable Geldof way â€“ he managed to get Roger to phone Dave and say â€œI think we should do thisâ€. With barely three weeks to rehearse in, all four of them agreed.

It might have been a disaster; it was a huge risk. Equally, it might have sparked a full reunion and tour, but that didnâ€™t happen either, and probably just as well. Instead what happened was 24 minutes when all the baggage and all the years fell away, and (with a little help, as ever, from their supporting cast) the four people who had been Pink Floyd during that short period when they were incapable of putting a foot wrong, stood on the same stage and did what they did best:

Iâ€™ll be honest, I sat there that Saturday night, barely able to believe what I was seeing, and watching it again now can still bring a tear to my eye â€“ Iâ€™m going to throw in one more post which tries to explain that â€“ Iâ€™ve been to concerts which meant more to me, and seen some things Iâ€™ll never forget, but that night stands alone. I know Iâ€™m about to review a whole other Pink Floyd album, but really â€“ the story ends here.

Syd Barrett died on July 7th, 2006. He had long since reverted to his birth name of Roger, and had no interest in Pink Floyd or the music scene generally for the last thirty years or more of his life. It is idle to speculate about what exactly happened to Syd; better to be grateful for what he did bring to Pink Floyd â€“ without him, none of this would have happened. Itâ€™s easy to be sad for him, or to project all kinds of things onto his post-fame life; perhaps the truth is that he had seen that life, and didnâ€™t want anything more to do with it.

Richard Wright died on September 15th, 2008, and with him died any hope of Pink Floyd ever performing again. For all that there were several years when he wasnâ€™t officially in the band, itâ€™s impossible to imagine the remaining members of the band performing those songs without Wrightâ€™s unique washes of keyboard â€“ he was an integral part of the sound; one of the main reasons that â€˜The Division Bellâ€™ sounds so much like a proper Floyd album is that Wright is propelling the sound along and filling in the corners with colour. He was perhaps a little unsung in his lifetime, but thereâ€™s a whole album devoted to recognising his contribution, and I like to think heâ€™d have approved.

Storm Thorgerson died on April 18th 2013. He was never in Pink Floyd, but he was most of the time â€˜of Pink Floydâ€™; he is as responsible as anyone for the way they are perceived.

So, is it any good?

Iâ€™ve heard it described as â€˜Endless Drivelâ€™, and thatâ€™s not fair. However, it is an album of outtakes and discarded offcuts, glued together with Gilmour overdubs, and putting it out as a fully-fledged Pink Floyd album seems contrary to the spirit of the whole enterprise.

Itâ€™s the only Pink Floyd album I donâ€™t own in any form, and having listened to it intently on Spotify over the past few days, I honestly donâ€™t feel the need to change that. Itâ€™s not terrible; in fact, in places, itâ€™s actually quite good, if somewhat backward-looking. Itâ€™s just that itâ€™s not, you know, necessary. You can, of course, make that claim for all the albums after â€˜The Wallâ€™, but they each have some form of saving grace â€“ this just doesnâ€™t contain anything which grabs my attention at all. One song at the end with lyrics does not an album make, and I would have been perfectly happy to live out the rest of my days with my memories. This doesnâ€™t sully the memories exactly; but it doesnâ€™t enhance them.

I can pretend it doesnâ€™t exist, I suppose. That will have to do.

Some things to consider if youâ€™re coming to this new:

Seven years went by; you would have been excused for assuming that Pink Floyd was a thing of the past at this point. In the meantime, all kinds of things happenedâ€¦

The tour for â€˜Momentary Lapse of Reasonâ€™ went on for two years (three if you count the Knebworth show in 1990), and the show was in two parts â€“ the first half kicked off with a shortened â€˜Shine Onâ€™, then played most of the new album; the second half was all the stuff people had actually come to hear. The Knebworth show was just the greatest hits package, and there was a famously shambolic (but visually impressive, even if it did contribute to the undermining of the cityâ€™s foundations) live show in Venice:

Thereâ€™s a live album of the tour â€“ â€˜Delicate Sound of Thunderâ€™ is a pretty good album, and the â€˜Lapseâ€™ songs do work better in a live context, having been properly rehearsed and worked over by all three of them. The huge cast of performers supporting the core members donâ€™t hurt, either, particularly Guy Prattâ€™s bass work, which could almost make you forget about Roger Watersâ€™ absence. Rick Wright was at some point in all of this absorbed back into the band (I have no idea how the legal stuff was worked out for that).

And then, silence. Waters had released â€˜Radio K.A.O.S.â€™ during this period, and toured it against the main bandâ€™s tour, which led to all sorts of petty (if you can believe that) stipulations about the inflatable pig, and, indeed, about whether members of Floyd were allowed to go to one of Rogerâ€™s shows (they werenâ€™t).

We heard â€˜The Tide is Turningâ€™ from KAOS earlier; hereâ€™s a very Eighties song from it:

In 1992, Waters released â€˜Amused to Deathâ€™, which to these ears is much closer to what Floyd might have sounded like with him still in the band:

Meanwhile, Gilmour and Waters went off to do a long distance car race in Mexico; thereâ€™s a film and some original music:

Early on, Gilmour managed to drive his car off a cliff, which nearly killed him and Steve Oâ€™Rourke, the tour manager, and also made the finished film look a little thin in places. Honestly, looking at that clip is probably enough for everyone; it gives you an idea of what it was all like. Mason credits the construction of the music for the film as providing the necessary impetus for going back to work on a new Pink Floyd album; in a radical move, all the members of the band went into the studio at the same time and created music together for the first time since â€˜Wish You Were Hereâ€™.

During the hiatus, Nick Mason did a couple of film soundtracks with Rick Fenn, and drummed for jazz trumpeter Michael Mantler. Rick Wright mainly sat around on a Greek island and counted his money, and David Gilmour worked with everyone from Paul McCartney to Hale and Pace. ( I am not putting up a link to his guitar solo on â€˜The Stonkâ€™; you can look that up for yourselves ğŸ˜€ )

There was no real sense for those of us out in the rest of the world, slowly turning middle aged, that there would ever be another Pink Floyd album; nor, I think, was there much demand for one. Surely it had run its course â€“ the live shows being a suitable way to go out. Heck, there was even a wonderfully crafted 20th anniversary CD edition of â€˜Dark Sideâ€™ to go on the coffee table and impress your dinner party guests with; we didnâ€™t need anything more.

Imagine the surprise and delight, then, when we read in Q magazine that â€˜The Division Bellâ€™ was imminentâ€¦

So, is it any good?

Well, when I said â€˜surprise and delightâ€™, I think I meant â€˜surprise and mild trepidationâ€™. The last one having been a bit of a stinker, what hope was there that this would be any better?

In truth, itâ€™s actually pretty good. I think I could still make a case for it not being a Pink Floyd album, but itâ€™s a lot closer â€“ Rick has a vocal, and his musical influence is all over this. The opening three tracks are pretty strong, I like â€˜Maroonedâ€™ as well; â€˜Wearing the Inside Outâ€™ is a glimpse of what Wright can do after all this time, and itâ€™s generally produced to sound like a Floyd record. The highlights are, perhaps inevitably, â€˜Keep Talkingâ€™ (yes, it was taken directly from a BT advert; yes, it could be anyone delivering those words, but it isnâ€™t, itâ€™s Steven Hawking) and â€˜High Hopesâ€™, which for more than twenty years sat perfectly as the final statement by a band calling themselves Pink Floyd. â€˜High Hopesâ€™ has a lot of what makes Floyd great in it, a terrific hook, melody and is lyrically satisfying. You come away from the album thinking that itâ€™s better than it really is, because it goes out on such a high.

However.

To be perfectly honest, itâ€™s a little blandly produced in places; Gilmourâ€™s voice doesnâ€™t work well enough on all the tracks, and itâ€™s too long. Sorry, Iâ€™m going to have to go off on a tangent here. Bear with me.

For about 20 years from the mid-sixties, record albums were constrained in length by the physical limitations of vinyl. You could just about get 50 minutes onto an LP, but you were dicing with the quality, and two sides of 20 minutes each was the accepted norm. That template became the default for pretty much anything â€“ to do a double album was a real risk â€“ who the hell has enough good material to fill that space â€“ especially if you have to deliver another one in six monthsâ€™ time? And, letâ€™s face it, there are a great many albums whose quality would only be diluted by forcing more music into the whole thing.

â€˜Dark Side of the Moonâ€™ is 43 minutes long. Since 1973, no-one has seriously argued that itâ€™s not enough; that it could have done with a few extra bits tacked on. Would â€˜Led Zeppelin 4â€™ be improved by a few extra tracks? Would â€˜Revolverâ€™ or â€˜Pet Soundsâ€™? How about â€˜Harvestâ€™, or â€˜Court and Sparkâ€™ or â€˜Back in Blackâ€™? Even â€˜Sergeant Pepperâ€™, which might have had â€˜Strawberry Fieldsâ€™ and â€˜Penny Laneâ€™ added on if the technology had allowed, wouldnâ€™t necessarily be better for it (but feel free to argue).

Along cane the CD, on which you could fit 74 minutes of music if you wanted (thereâ€™s a story about that limit being set because someone wanted to hear the whole of Beethovenâ€™s 9th Symphony in one sitting; I meant to look it up, but Iâ€™m out of time). Of course, some bands took the opportunity to add more twiddliness â€“ â€˜Brothers in Armsâ€™ on CD is several minutes longer than the LP version; there are no extra songs, just extra solos and other assorted bits of styrofoam packaging; it would take a few years for people to really get the idea that the CD was the base format, and if it didnâ€™t fit on LP or cassette, that was too bad â€“ all the money was coming from the sale of shiny discs. Of course, selling people a CD and charging full price for it was never going to fly if there was only 40 minutes of music on it â€“ re-releases started to have all kinds of stuff jammed on them to give â€˜value for moneyâ€™ (I particularly dislike the CD re-release of â€˜Close to the Edgeâ€™, which has inferior demo versions of two tracks, as well as a cover of Paul Simonâ€™s â€˜Americaâ€™, which doesnâ€™t fit with the mood of the rest of it. Itâ€™s horrible, but sold a lot of units to completists.

â€˜The Division Bellâ€™ suffers from this propensity to extend: it is a full 24 minutes longer than â€˜Dark Sideâ€™, and with the best will in the world, the only possible reason for that is people in windowless offices with spreadsheets. Some songs could be shorter, others could be omitted altogether, and if you got it down to about 40 minutes, youâ€™d have something which just might sit alongside the seventies albums.

Although it still wouldnâ€™t have Roger Waters on it, and so doesnâ€™t really sound properly like Pink Floyd.

However, as a final statement, I always thought it worked pretty well â€“ itâ€™s sort of concept-y and has some themes and motifs which work; some decent sound effects; a great cover, and three quarters of Pink Floyd not only playing on it, but actively involved in the construction of the whole thing. And I like Guy Prattâ€™s bass, so thereâ€™s that.

Some things to consider if youâ€™re coming to this new:

Now then. I suppose the easy way out for me would be to say â€œat this point, Roger Waters left Pink Floydâ€, and carry on, but thereâ€™s so much packed into that short verb that Iâ€™m going to have to expand a littleâ€¦

There was no tour to support â€˜The Final Cutâ€™; I canâ€™t imagine how a tour would have worked at that point. The first thing which happened after the release of â€˜The Final Cutâ€™ was that Capitol records in the US released a compilation called â€˜Worksâ€™ as some kind of spoiler. You might remember Capitol released everything up to â€˜Dark Sideâ€™, but were considered ineffective by the band, and the contract wasnâ€™t renewed, which is why Gilmour had to re-record â€˜Moneyâ€™ for the last compilation album. â€˜Worksâ€™ consists largely of alternate takes of some of the better known early songs, â€˜Several Species of Small Furry Animalsâ€¦â€™ for some reason, and a previously unreleased track from the â€˜Ummagummaâ€™ sessions called â€˜Embryo:

After that, the band went their own separate ways and recorded various solo albums. I realise I missed out Nick Masonâ€™s â€˜Fictitious Sportsâ€™ last time round â€“ it came out in between the last two Floyd albums. Itâ€™s not really a solo album, unless youâ€™re going to be honest and call it a Carla Bley solo album. Bley is a highly regarded jazz pianist; somehow Mason agreed to record an album of her songs, with Robert Wyatt on vocals. Mason did at least play all the drums on it. Itâ€™s interesting, but itâ€™s not Pink Floyd (thereâ€™s a hint of Zappa on this one, for example):

Mason then collaborated with Rick Fenn, at the time guitarist in 10cc, on another album called â€˜Profilesâ€™. This one is mainly instrumental, and does feature David Gilmour on one track:

Neither album sold particularly well, but it didnâ€™t really matter; finances were much more stable than theyâ€™d ever been.

Gilmourâ€™s solo career continued â€“ â€˜About Faceâ€™ came out in 1984, featuring a couple of tracks with lyrics by Pete Townshend, and definitely has its moments:

Rick Wright released an album called â€˜Identityâ€™ under the name â€˜Zeeâ€™ â€“ a collaboration with Dave Harris of Fashion. Itâ€™s a bit Eightiesâ€¦

â€¦ actually, itâ€™s a lot Eighties.

And, of course, we canâ€™t ignore Roger. â€˜The Pros and Cons of Hitch Hikingâ€™ came out in 1984, in direct competition with Gilmour. It probably deserves a post of its own, and for all that itâ€™s off-topic for this, it might have been the follow up to â€˜Animalsâ€™. Itâ€™s â€“ to these ears â€“ pretty good, worth some of your time. The title track features Eric Clapton doing what Gilmour would otherwise have been doing, and you can see how Waters is simply continuing what he believes to be the Pink Floyd sound:

Waters and Gilmour toured more or less at the same time, Roger doing much more Floyd material and â€“ without ever really saying so â€“ presenting himself as the natural successor to the band. Even at this point, thereâ€™s a suspicion that, if he had been a little more flexible, things might have gone differently.

The crunch came when Gilmour and Mason agreed to try doing another Pink Floyd album. Waters flatly refused to be involved, as in his opinion, the band had broken up. Gilmour countered with the observation that the record company were keen for a new Floyd album, and the only thing preventing it from happening was Waters refusal to take part. If he wasnâ€™t going to contribute, he had better formally resign from the band and let them get on with it.

At this point, things got messy. Both parties sued each other â€“ or threatened to â€“ Waters to prevent the others from using the Pink Floyd name, the others to force him to work with them again (that would have ended well). Eventually, faced with what he imagined would be financial ruin, Waters backed down, resigned from the various companies (he had apparently left the band some time before, but was still a director of the overall organisation), and told Gilmour that he would never make another Floyd album. I believe the expression is â€˜red rag to a bullâ€™.

The details of the whole situation are unbearably complex â€“ in Masonâ€™s book, he kind of skates around most of it -but what we do know is unedifying and testament to what happens when large egos and a lot of money slosh around in a band which was based originally on hippy ideals. If you want some more insight, thereâ€™s a great Rolling Stone article from the time which tries to cut through the tangle.

So, with none of the dust settled, and Roger Waters out on the road playing Floyd music, Gilmour set about creating â€˜Dave Gilmourâ€™s Pink Floydâ€™. Recording started on Gilmourâ€™s houseboat in the Thames (I imagine there was all sorts of red tape preventing the use of Britannia Row; none of the band particularly liked it anyway). Rick Wright was able to guest on a couple of tracks, but his contributions were minimal, mainly for legal reasons (he signed a piece of paper at one point agreeing that he would never be allowed back in the band). Mason does play drums in a few places, but confessed to being extremely rusty after four years of pissing about in sportscars, and in any case overwhelmed by the new technology available. The upshot is that â€˜A Momentary Lapse of Reasonâ€™ is pretty much Gilmourâ€™s third solo album. It sold a lot better than the other two, though â€“ it had the Pink Floyd name on the front, and a Hipgnosis cover. Thereâ€™s also a band photo inside. I say a band photo; itâ€™s Dave and Nick leaning against each other as if they were on the poster for a Matthew McConaughey film.

So, is it any good?

No.

Sorry, but it really isnâ€™t. For a start, it is in no way a Pink Floyd album. Listening to it for this has been a chore; itâ€™s not even as good as Gilmourâ€™s other solo work up to this point. If it wasnâ€™t for â€˜On The Turning Awayâ€™ and â€“ to an extent â€“ â€˜Learning to Flyâ€™, I doubt Iâ€™d ever listen to it again.
